We used the latter to ensure the unit of analysis involved only independent studies [14,75,98]. 8 The two data files with five datasets are necessary because of an interesting nomological network difference between PMT and the EPPM: PMT uses two first-order representations of threat (severity + vulnerability) and two first-order representations of efficacy (self-efficacy + response efficacy). Conversely, the EPPM combines and uses these as second-order constructs called threat and efficacy. Thus, to test the EPPM-related models (2, 4, and 6), all the existing first-order threats and efficacies needed to be collapsed into second-order constructs and we could not use any first-order versions of these. By contrast, all the PMT-related models required only first-order versions of these constructs, whereas any second-order version had to be excluded. 9 If any reliability data were missing, we used an assumed level of .80, but only if the study's other reliabilities were .80 or higher and the authors followed expected methodological procedures, as suggested by research [3,11]. Otherwise, the study was dropped. 10 We also followed other meta-analytic studies in dealing with results that are generalizable across a broad domain [64,133]; consequently, we did not consider the number of measurement items used for a given measure and treated all such measures equally, as suggested by leading guides to meta-analysis [2,14,22]. However, we did gather reliability statistics for each measure (α) to make adjustments for measurement reliability, as suggested by leading MASEM research [11]. 11 Assessing the file drawer problem for MASEM, including TSSEM, is still in its infancy [32]. Thus, we used conventional meta-analysis (i.e., analyzing single correlations instead of correlation matrices) to assess the file drawer problem. We used the random-effects model to aggregate the observed effect sizes of each hypothesis in the best fit models (Models 3, 5, 6). The observed effect sizes were Fisher r-to-z transformed before applying the random-effects model [13]. The resultant aggregated effect sizes were used to assess the file drawer problem [130]. 12 A type II error occurs when a statistical test fails to reject a null hypothesis when it is false. Statistical power is the probability that a statistical test will reject a null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true [43]. 13 Multicollinearity exists when a factor in the research model is highly correlated with one or more factors [6]. 14 The VIF score of a focal predictor is calculated as 1 divided by 1 -R 2 , where R 2 is the R-squared value obtained by regressing that focal predictor on all other predictors in the model [63,108]. 15 See the following URL for full documentation of and access to "metaSEM" for implementing TSSEM: https://cran.rproject.org/web/packages/metaSEM/vignettes/Examples.html 16 TSSEM has already been extensively developed and compared to other techniques (e.g., traditional MASEM, SEM, regression, and meta-analysis) and has been peer reviewed in multiple elite interdisciplinary journals, including multiple publications in Psychological Methods, the top APA journal on methodology and statistics [27,31,38,79]; Structural Equation Modeling, the leading interdisciplinary journal on SEM [28,29,39]; Behavior Research Methods [30,78]; Journal of Applied Psychology [35];

Research Synthesis Methods [37,40]; Health Psychology Review [41]; Multivariate Behavioral Research [77]; and other outlets. However, to date, its use is absent from top management journals, which are still using the older, flawed version of MASEM. 17 To resolve this issue with traditional MASEM, the PCM in TSSEM is not an observed correlation matrix and is not used as an "inputted covariance matrix" to fit the structural model (as in traditional MASEM). Only the final covariance matrix is used to fit the model with a CB-SEM analysis. 18 To resolve this issue with traditional MASEM, TSSEM accounts for the sample variation and interdependency among effect sizes across primary studies by weighting the PCM using the ACM [38,121]. Such weighting means that the larger the sampling variation, the lesser the weight given to the correlations, an approach consistent with traditional meta-analysis [32,75].

Consequently, TSSEM provides each observation with its appropriate weight to be considered when estimating the final parameter values [38,121]. 19 To resolve this issue with traditional MASEM, through the weighting approach, TSSEM uses the total sample size corresponding to each effect size to compute the final covariance matrix rather than using ad hoc approaches such as harmonic mean or mean sample [32,38]. Consequently, in TSSEM, the type I, type II, and standard errors of parameter estimates are controlled so that correct inferences can be made from them [39,108]. 20 A fixed-effects model assumes effect-size homogeneity, in which a single true population effect size applies to all the primary studies included in the analyses [108]. This model applies when primary studies in a meta-analytic dataset share common conditions and measures. Thus, the pooled effect size is considered the population effect size, and effect-size variations across studies are attributed to sampling errors [108]. 21 By contrast, a random-effects model assumes effect-size heterogeneity, in which each study has its own true population effect size [76]. This model applies when there is variation in study conditions and measures, as is the norm for organizational or behavioral datasets. Thus, the pooled effect size is the mean of the distribution of effect sizes, and the effect-size variations across studies are attributed to sampling errors and between-study heterogeneity [108]. 22 The latest standard is to exclude nonpositive definite matrices before proceeding with the TSSEM Stage 1 analysis [143]. A nonpositive definite matrix indicates that the values of the matrix are inconsistent [41] and challenge the structural equation modeling assumptions [32,130]. Adjusting effect sizes for reliability, a procedure applied in our analysis as is common for metaanalysis, is one of the sources of nonpositive definiteness [41,143,159]. 23 A good-fitting model will have a comparative fit index (CFI) and Tucker-Lewis index (TLI) of 0.9 or higher, a root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) of 0.08 or lower, and standard root mean residual (SRMR) values below 0.08 [72,108]. 24 Crucially, the chi-square test is sensitive to large sample sizes such that the larger the sample (e.g., > 400) the higher the likelihood that the null hypothesis is rejected [121]. This issue is more pronounced in TSSEM (and traditional MASEM) because where the total samples are extremely large and, as a result, the exact fit rarely holds [78]. Thus, in conducting TSSEM, we use RMSEA, SRMR, CFI, and TLI to assess model fit, as is the standard TSSEM practice [78,121]. 25 The AIC is an especially effective means of non-nested model selection, because it estimates the quality of each model relative to that of each of the other models [5,16,101,141]. The BIC has properties comparable to those of the AIC but is slightly more conservative in penalizing potentially unwieldy non-nested models that have a higher likelihood of overfitting. Like the AIC, the BIC is recognized by leading methodologists as an effective criterion for model selection among a finite set of non-nested models, based on a likelihood function, with the lowest BIC indicating the most preferred model [111,122,152]. However, in both cases, these must be based on the same covariance matrix, and thus they cannot be used to compare models with different variables and different datasets. This is why we can only horse race Models 4 and 6. 26 An indirect effect between a given pair of independent and dependent variables indicates the effect of that independent variable on the dependent variable transmitted through an intervening (i.e., mediating) variable [108]. The indirect effect is estimated using the product of the direct effects on the indirect route between the independent and dependent variables [108,143]. For example, in Model 6, the indirect effect of 0.090 (0.049, 0.130) between T2n and PM is the product of T2n  Fear and Fear  PM direct effects. This indirect effect indicates the extent to which the effect of T2n on PM is transmitted through the intervening variable, Fear. The total effect refers to the sum of the direct and indirect effects between a given pair of independent and dependent variables [108]. For example, in Model 6, the total effect 0.194 (0.157, 0.230) is the sum of the direct effect of 0.104 (0.046, 0.162) and the indirect effect of 0.090 (0.049, 0.130) between T2n and PM. The total effect if 0.194 (0.157, 0.230) indicates that a one standard deviation increase in T2n results in 0.194 standard deviation increase in PM. 27 For example, in PMT Model 5, the average efficacy effect size is .226 and the average threat effect size is .0585, for a 384% higher effect; in EPPM Model 6, efficacy is .307 and threat is .104, for a 295% higher effect. 28 Response costs work well only in incomplete models when maladaptive rewards are not considered. 29 Only maladaptive rewards works as a positive predictor of DM, and only threat severity acts as a negative predictor.

Provides incomplete data and is not in scope. Duplicate data (20.0%) indicates papers that use the same data that we have already included in the meta-analysis from another published source. Most commonly, this occurs when an available dissertation chapter is published as a journal article, or when a conference paper is published as a journal article.

Lack of data (30.9%) indicates papers that do not provide sufficient data for analysis. The primary reasons are that some of these are qualitative or review papers, some are research-in-progress with preliminary incomplete data, and some are complete empirical projects where the authors were unwilling to provide the correlation data necessary to conduct meta-analysis (a few empirical papers are published in journals without normally expected descriptive statistics, correlation tables, or measurement model statistics that are necessary for meta-analysis; in all cases, we requested these from the authors at least twice).

Measures (10.3%) indicates a study that cannot be included because there are clear measurement or operationalization issues (e.g., use of 1-item measures or not using validated scales) or because the reliability of the measures is below acceptable thresholds.
Not a security study (11.4%) indicates a fear-appeals study that uses an in-scope theory but in fact is not a securityrelated study (e.g., personal health or physical protection context).

div.head: Theory (27.4%)
div.p: indicates a study that is on topic but does not use a fear-appeals related theory (e.g., PMT, EPPM, HBM, TTAT) that is compatible with the assumptions and measures of our meta-analysis. The most common examples are studies based in DT, TPB, RCT, or TAM. The intentions to respond to and reduce the emotions and their outcomes that arise from a perceived security/privacy threat, by following a generally defensive path counter to protection motivation [468,469]. This is the fear-control portion of EPPM (a negative, non-protective response to threat). PMT: fear Fear; FEAR (4)

PMT and EPPM
div.p: Fear, fear arousal, fear of threat, cognitive fear, emotional fear, physical fear A negatively valenced emotional response, physical response, or cognitive response representing a response that arises from a threat [68,344,470]. The perceived effectiveness of the recommended, adaptive security/privacy response [68,170,242,317].

PMT: selfefficacy Self-efficacy; SEF (5) PMT Self-efficacy, perceived behavioral control, coping self-efficacy, high locus of control, password selfefficacy, privacy self-efficacy, self-confidence (to protect)
The perceived ability to perform the recommended, adaptive security/privacy behavior [68,170,242,317].
EPPM: efficacy evaluation (2nd order)
Efficacy (2 nd ); EFF_2ND (9)

div.head: EPPM
div.p: Coping appraisal, efficacy (general), personal coping, coping adaptiveness Individual's perception of his/her ability to follow a recommended, adaptive security/privacy response successfully and the perceived effectiveness of the recommended action [468,470]. This is a combination of PMT's self-efficacy and response efficacy. The fail-safe k value represents the number of studies with null results needed to render a significant meta-analytically synthesized effect size nonsignificant. Fail-Safe k threshold (the value that must be exceeded) = 5k+10, where k refers to the number of observed effect sizes corresponding to a weighted effect size; Fail-Safe k test = "Yes," if the Fail-Safe k value exceeds the Fail-Safe k Threshold, and "No" if not. Malr = maladaptive rewards; PM = protection motivation; Self = self-efficacy; RE = response efficacy; Rec = response costs; Tsev = threat severity; Tvul = threat vulnerability , including a lack of multicollinearity in all of the predictors for three models. E2n = efficacy 2 nd order; Malr = maladaptive rewards; Self = self-efficacy; RE = response efficacy; Rec = response costs; T2n = threat 2 nd order; Tsev = threat severity; Tvul = threat vulnerability

figure.figDesc: test our hypotheses for the six models, we pooled five large datasets (the n of each ranged from145,331

row.cell: to 153,507) from the two data files and analyzed them with TSSEM, the second-generation form of
MASEM, which requires two distinct stages of analysis: in Stage 1 the pooled correlation matrix (PCM)
and the asymptotic covariance matrix (ACM) are produced; and (2) in Stage 2 the PCM and the ACM are
used to fit SEMs using CB-SEM. TSSEM is implemented through the open-access R library metaSEM,
which has been supported, extensively tested, documented, and refined by scores of leading
interdisciplinary researchers for over a decade. 15
